This is just bad. Why do you want a board game that is pretty much the same as the single player board game. This shouldn't exist.
I'm giving it a 1 because people are giving it a 10

TL;DR:
- I love the video game, have put ~400h in. This is a low effort cash grab.
- Game plays like multiplayer solitaire despite of "co-op". Co-op itself is laughably bad and shallow. There goes your only reason to get this game.
- No new content. Everything is either the same or dumbed down.
- Simultaneous turns dont really work.
- Plays at least 3x longer than the video game (4.5 hours)
- Cost at least 14x more than the video game.

As per video review, It's WAY too close to the video game. If you've played the video game to the point where you revealed all the unlockables, there's almost zero new content in this game.

The cards are either exactly the same as the video game, dumbed down / simplified due to physical limitations or infused with a very shallow co-op aspect. If you like any unique mechanic in the video game, it's probably gone.

Co-op is really pasted on and is laughable that it becomes the selling point of this game. There is basically no new co-op specific mechanic (there is actually one and it's absolutely useless). All you do is either shield someone else, apply weak to a monster to reduce damage and save someone, apply vulnerable to double someone else's attack or kill another enemy targeting an almost dead player. How is this even anywhere enough to counteract the ~14x more cost, ~3x more play duration and the dumbed down mechanics? Literally get any other co-op game and you would probably get the same co-op feeling or better, because the co-op in this game is sooooooo shallow and uninteresting. In all my sessions I have in this game, I always wished I had played an actual board game and not just a crappy copy of a video game.

One tiny little niche: If you have never played the video game, you'll probably like this way more than I did. I'd suggest you try it on Steam first (and refund if you dont like). But then argument becomes a full circle, where if you like the video game, the board game offers nothing new and is just a worse version in every single way. Definitely try the board game if you have the chance. But I would never recommend you to blindly but this game, ever.

A completely accurate representation of the computer game rendered into cardboard. Not a second of thought has been put into adapting it into a board game or how it would actually play. As a result this is ridiculously bloated with fiddly faffing. Your play area will be surrounded by dozens of trinkets you have to check before doing any action, tracks you will run from start to finish in every fight, tokens toggled before and after you do anything, etc, etc. The scale of tasks required to complete one small fight, even one action, is just all wrong. Each fight is the equivalent of a whole game of Dominion, but results in the opportunity to make a single card change to your deck.

Slay the Spire is an irreverent, independently designed computer game that was crafted with care to prioritise game play over graphics and other commercial bells and whistles, by creators who clearly love board games. It is innovative, elegant and minimalist. This game is nothing like it.

If you love Slay the Spire and want to play the board game that inspired it, play Dominion (easy to solo play online, too). If you want a sprawling fantasy adventure that feels like a computer games, is built around deck building and full of meaningful battles and thought out design, play Mage Knight.
Played through it once and realized I already owned this game and logged 40+ hours with it on my PC. What a waste of money.

This flawed experiment tries to keep too much (almost everything, save scaling down some numbers and making a few minor tweaks to some status conditions) from the excellent videogame, which had heavily leveraged having a computer available to manage status conditions, damage modifiers, and on-trigger abilities for you. Managing all of that yourself is tedious to say the least. Adding cooperative play is a fun idea, but by not removing enough complexity elsewhere, that just further contributes to game length, which already feels excessive - you're looking at over an hour per Act for a two-player game, at which point the game really outstays its welcome.

I think a good game could have been made by designing a different combat system with a totally different level of abstraction, keeping the spirit, fun deck-building, and interesting random encounters of the original videogame, but with a new design to ensure a snappy and fun experience. Instead, this design has tried to keep too much of the original and feels like a mediocre remake in card and plastic, rather than an actual adaptation; in other words, it's pretty much exactly what you might fear "Slay the Spire: The Board Game" would be.

The game difficulty is BRUTAL solo. It was clearly designed to be a multiplayer adaptation of the video game and solo was tacked on as an option, but the imbalance between player counts is off the charts. The mechanics are very fun (it's just Slay the Spire which is fun!) but prepare to lose non-stop in frustrating, un-fun ways if you're playing solo.

The game also has one of the worst rulebooks I've seen (and I have the most recent updated version). The sleeves also, which are mandatory, are poor quality and start peeling after a handful of runs. My game also had sleeves of different sizes so you can feel the difference between cards I sleeved earlier and cards I sleeved later.

This is precisely what I feared a Slay the Spire Board Game would be--it's a far too faithful adaptation of the video game to a physical medium.

But why would I want an almost direct analog of the excellent video game? I would not--the computer is so critical to tracking so many effects, health, numbers, not to mention the sheer shuffling and drawing. The video game lets you play runs in a snappy and enjoyable timeframe, the board game by trying to keep almost everything makes the players do far too much tracking and bookkeeping themselves, making the game take way too long for the decisions and fun being had.

The one positive is that the board game does at least allow for cooperative play with up to four players--that is neat. It's fun to get to go on a run together through the acts, but mostly it makes me wish for that to be an option in the video game. It also has the issue many cooperative games do, in that there's almost certainly a best answer for what everyone should do on a given turn, but to talk it out and work through it is tedious and boring and unfun and prone to quarterbacking. Yet playing fast and loose by the seat of your pants might get you all killed, so the game rewards you for going slow and methodical and making the whole experience take way too long.

I'm pretty unimpressed by the team that made this--they essentially figured a way to port everything in to a physical way and only made the game a bit smoother by adjusting all the numbers down a bit. A team actually willing to really adapt the core of Slay the Spire by actually design some ideas to make it shine in a board game format is something I'd be very interested in. Sadly this is not that at all, and I'll stick to playing the video game except on those very rare cases I'll get talked in to playing this again before remembering why this system is a video game in the first place.

It's an impressive translation of the videogame, which I guess speaks to how economically designed the videogame was to begin with. But it's missing the most important tool in your kit for dealing with roguelikes; the ragequit. If you're have a bad luck run there's no new tools introduced in the boardgame to mitigate the bad draws, but you can't just quit and restart because you have 3 friends who are invested. The whole thing just moves too slowly to hit the dopamine-frenzy-of-acquisition from powerups that gives roguelikes their addictive quality.

Never played the video game, but was happy to try the tabletop version given the positive rumors. Not bad, but less appealing than expected as a multiplayer experience.

I can see how a solo runthrough would be a satisfying puzzle. Especially for people preferring less randomness, since there isn't a combat roll or fate deck to be found. For me, the mostly deterministic approach leads to less tension and emotional engagement.

In our 4p session, battle rounds looked something like this:

- 1-2 people would quickly throw down cards and assign damage.
- The others would scratch their heads, wondering if preplanning would help. Invariably, this would cause the original gunjumpers to rewind their plays.
- A new plan would develop and tentatively proceed, with a high probability for additional take-backs.
- The cards would eventually settle, with all combatants mostly content.

Since there is no hidden information, StS is a classic example of how nonrandom combat may as well be handled by the most experienced and/or least tired player. After all, there's a good chance that there's a single best way to assign damage, shields, and other effects.

I can also see StS overstaying its welcome. We called it after a one-act victory, which was appreciated. Two acts might be OK with a speedy group, since you'd see cooler upgrades in that format. Three acts is right out.

Ironically, I can see people unfamiliar with the original sorta liking the physical implementation, but wondering whether it would be better for a computer to handle the setup, logistics, etc. Yeah, could be. :/

The cardplay of StS is really, really good and I do appreciate the fact that in this iteration of the game rules have been streamlined and cards are balanced differently. Each card feels like their counterpart in the original, but due to changes in rules and values, you have to reassess a lot of cards which was a welcome surprise.

However, I really dislike the amount of upkeep and fiddlyness. Setting up a new act doesn't take long, but it's painfull nonetheless. With the Silent in particular I feel like I'm spending most of my time moving poison markers around instead of playing the game.

The custom sleeves are horrible and a few already broke.

Also, the game is too easy for me. While you can up the Ascension level, at some point the game becomes frustrating and RNG takes over. While that is fine in a 10-30 minute run in the video game, it is beyond annoying in the boardgame where starting a new run is not just one loading screen away. Hence, the well balanced entry level game could have been a bit more challenging in my opinion.

I'm not really interested in playing this ever again, as the upkeep is just too bad for me personally and I think the videogame is a better fit for me.

Le Deck building est une mécanique que j'affectionne beaucoup. Il partait donc avec un à priori positif. Et bien il m'a convaincu.
Mise en place relativement rapide, jouable en vrai solo et en multi (grosse plus value car on peut s'entraider) principe d'une mini- campagne (3 actes, avec sauvegarde facile entre ceux-ci), amélioration du deck au fur et à mesure de la partie et on débloque du contenu pour les prochaines parties.
Particularité par rapport à un Deck building classique, c'est qu'on ne vomit pas notre main de cartes, on a des points d'énergie pour jouer nos cartes, il faudra souvent faire des choix.
Juste il faut avoir à l'esprit que ce n'est pas un Die and Retry comme Dead Cell. Ici, il n'y a pas de contenu débloqué que l'on ajoute à notre début de partie. Corolaire : on peut très bien arrivé à la fin des 3 Actes dès la première fois (c'est d'ailleurs ce qui met arrivé avec La Silencieuse ).
- Point Négatif : chaque héros possède 1/2 mécaniques spécifiques ( exemple les Dagues et le Poison pour la Silencieuse). Cependant les héros ne possèdent aucune carte dans leur deck de départ jouant avec leurs mécaniques spécifiques. Il faut attendre d'en avoir lorsque l'on gagne des cartes. Je trouve qu'ils auraient pu un peu plus personnalisé les decks de départ. Heureusement on en gagne rapidement et on a le choix entre 3 cartes.
- Autre point négatif : si la présence des sleeves opaques est appréciable ( nécessaires car les cartes sont R/V pour s'améliorer), ceux-ci ont une tendance à s'abîmer très vite

My wife and I played this twice today. I am really impressed with how streamlined everything in the game is. At first, I thought it would be a chore to set up and run, but I was wrong. The insert helps to ease that by keeping everything coordinated and organized.

The play itself is quite rewarding--you get something new after each combat, and the choices on the path you follow give you a chance to decide on a shorter or longer game.

The use of the die is genuinely inspired. Everything that has a variety of outcomes triggers off the same die. And, for a change, I can actually always remember to roll it each time.

The only negative comment, so far, is that the art and monsters aren't that interesting to look at.I don't know what informs the art style, but I've seen a few things like this in the past (Neow typifies this), and it doesn't clisk with me.
